For the relative orientation of the co-ordinate systems indicated in Fig. 2, the x-axes of both systems pernumently coincide. In the present case we can divide the problem into parts by considering first only events which are localised on the xxx-axis. Any such event is represented with respect to the co-ordinate system KKK by the abscissa xxx and the time ttt, and with respect to the system K1K^1K1 by the abscissa x′x'x′ and the time t′t't′. We require to find x′x'x′ and t′t't′ when xxx and ttt are given.

A light-signal, which is proceeding along the positive axis of xxx, is transmitted according to the equation

x=ctx = ctx=ct

or

x−ct=0(1)\tag{1} x - ct = 0x−ct=0(1)

Since the same light-signal has to be transmitted relative to K1K^1K1 with the velocity ccc, the propagation relative to the system K1K^1K1 will be represented by the analogous formula

x′−ct′=0(2)\tag{2} x' - ct' = 0x′−ct′=0(2)

Those space-time points (events) which satisfy (1) must also satisfy (2). Obviously this will be the case when the relation

(x′−ct′)=λ(x−ct)(3)\tag{3} (x' - ct') = \lambda (x - ct)(x′−ct′)=λ(x−ct)(3)

is fulfilled in general, where λ\lambdaλ indicates a constant; for, according to (3), the disappearance of (x−ct)(x - ct)(x−ct) involves the disappearance of (x′−ct′)(x' - ct')(x′−ct′).

If we apply quite similar considerations to light rays which are being transmitted along the negative x-axis, we obtain the condition

(x′+ct′)=μ(x+ct)(4)\tag{4} (x' + ct') = \mu (x + ct)(x′+ct′)=μ(x+ct)(4)

By adding (or subtracting) equations (3) and (4), and introducing for convenience the constants aaa and bbb in place of the constants λ\lambdaλ and μ\muμ, where

a=λ+μ2a = \frac{\lambda+\mu}{2}a=2λ+μ​

and

a=λ−μ2a = \frac{\lambda-\mu}{2}a=2λ−μ​

we obtain the equations

x′=ax−bctct′=act−bx}(5)\tag{5} \left. \begin{array}{rcl} x' &=& ax-bct \\ ct' &=& act-bx \end{array} \right\} x′ct′​==​ax−bctact−bx​}(5)

We should thus have the solution of our problem, if the constants aaa and bbb were known. These result from the following discussion.

For the origin of K1K^1K1 we have permanently x′=0x' = 0x′=0, and hence according to the first of the equations (5)

x=bcatx = \frac{bc}{a}tx=abc​t

If we call vvv the velocity with which the origin of K1K^1K1 is moving relative to KKK, we then have

v=bca(6)\tag{6} v=\frac{bc}{a}v=abc​(6)

The same value vvv can be obtained from equations (a5), if we calculate the velocity of another point of K1K^1K1 relative to KKK, or the velocity (directed towards the negative xxx-axis) of a point of KKK with respect to K′K'K′. In short, we can designate vvv as the relative velocity of the two systems.

Furthermore, the principle of relativity teaches us that, as judged from KKK, the length of a unit measuring-rod which is at rest with reference to K1K^1K1 must be exactly the same as the length, as judged from K′K'K′, of a unit measuring-rod which is at rest relative to KKK. In order to see how the points of the xxx-axis appear as viewed from KKK, we only require to take a “snapshot” of K1K^1K1 from KKK; this means that we have to insert a particular value of ttt (time of KKK), e.g. t=0t = 0t=0. For this value of ttt we then obtain from the first of the equations (5)

x′=axx' = axx′=ax

Two points of the x′x'x′-axis which are separated by the distance Δx′=I\Delta x' = IΔx′=I when measured in the K1K^1K1 system are thus separated in our instantaneous photograph by the distance

Δx=Ia(7)\tag{7} \Delta x = \frac{I}{a}Δx=aI​(7)

But if the snapshot be taken from K′(t′=0)K'(t' = 0)K′(t′=0), and if we eliminate ttt from the equations (a5), taking into account the expression (6), we obtain

x′=a(I−v2c2)xx' = a \left( I - \frac{v^2}{c^2} \right) xx′=a(I−c2v2​)x

From this we conclude that two points on the xxx-axis separated by the distance III (relative to KKK) will be represented on our snapshot by the distance

Δx′=a(I−v2c2)(7a)\tag{7a} \Delta x' = a \left( I - \frac{v^2}{c^2} \right)Δx′=a(I−c2v2​)(7a)

But from what has been said, the two snapshots must be identical; hence Δx\Delta xΔx in (7) must be equal to Δx′\Delta x'Δx′ in (7a), so that we obtain

a=II−v2c2(7b)\tag{7b} a = \frac{I}{I-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}a=I−c2v2​I​(7b)

The equations (6) and (7b) determine the constants aaa and bbb. By inserting the values of these constants in (5), we obtain the first and the fourth of the equations given in Section XI.

x′=x−vtI−v2c2 t′=t−vc2xI−v2c2}(8)\tag{8} \left. \begin{array}{rcl} x' &=& \frac{x-vt}{\sqrt{I-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}} \\ ~ \\ t' &=& \frac{t-\frac{v}{c^2}x}{\sqrt{I-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}} \end{array} \right\} x′ t′​==​I−c2v2​​x−vt​I−c2v2​​t−c2v​x​​⎭⎪⎪⎪⎬⎪⎪⎪⎫​(8)

Thus we have obtained the Lorentz transformation for events on the xxx-axis. It satisfies the condition

x′2−c2t′2=x2−c2t2(8a)\tag{8a} x'^2 - c^2t'^2 = x^2 - c^2t^2x′2−c2t′2=x2−c2t2(8a)

The extension of this result, to include events which take place outside the xxx-axis, is obtained by retaining equations (8) and supplementing them by the relations

y′=yz′=z}(9)\tag{9} \left. \begin{array}{rcl} y' &=& y \\ z' &=& z \end{array} \right\}y′z′​==​yz​}(9)

In this way we satisfy the postulate of the constancy of the velocity of light in vacuo for rays of light of arbitrary direction, both for the system KKK and for the system K′K'K′. This may be shown in the following manner.

We suppose a light-signal sent out from the origin of KKK at the time t=0t = 0t=0. It will be propagated according to the equation

r=x2+y2+z2=ctr = \sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2} = ctr=x2+y2+z2​=ct

or, if we square this equation, according to the equation

x2+y2+z2=c2t2=0(10)\tag{10} x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = c^2t^2 = 0x2+y2+z2=c2t2=0(10)

It is required by the law of propagation of light, in conjunction with the postulate of relativity, that the transmission of the signal in question should take place—as judged from K1K^1K1—in accordance with the corresponding formula

r′=ct′r' = ct'r′=ct′

or,

x′2+y′2+z′2−c2t′2=0(10a)\tag{10a} x'^2 + y'^2 + z'^2 - c^2t'^2 = 0x′2+y′2+z′2−c2t′2=0(10a)

In order that equation (10a) may be a consequence of equation (10), we must have

x′2+y′2+z′2−c2t′2=σ(x2+y2+z2−c2t2)(11)\tag{11} x'^2 + y'^2 + z'^2 - c^2t'^2 = \sigma (x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - c^2t^2)x′2+y′2+z′2−c2t′2=σ(x2+y2+z2−c2t2)(11)

Since equation (8a) must hold for points on the xxx-axis, we thus have σ=I\sigma = Iσ=I. It is easily seen that the Lorentz transformation really satisfies equation (11) for σ=I\sigma = Iσ=I; for (11) is a consequence of (8a) and (9), and hence also of (8) and (9). We have thus derived the Lorentz transformation.

The Lorentz transformation represented by (8) and (9) still requires to be generalised. Obviously it is immaterial whether the axes of K1K^1K1 be chosen so that they are spatially parallel to those of KKK. It is also not essential that the velocity of translation of K1K^1K1 with respect to KKK should be in the direction of the xxx-axis. A simple consideration shows that we are able to construct the Lorentz transformation in this general sense from two kinds of transformations, viz. from Lorentz transformations in the special sense and from purely spatial transformations. which corresponds to the replacement of the rectangular co-ordinate system by a new system with its axes pointing in other directions.

Mathematically, we can characterise the generalised Lorentz transformation thus:

It expresses x′,y′,x′,t′x', y', x', t'x′,y′,x′,t′, in terms of linear homogeneous functions of x,y,x,tx, y, x, tx,y,x,t, of such a kind that the relation

x′2+y′2+z′2−c2t′2=x2+y2+z2−c2t2(11a)\tag{11a} x'^2 + y'^2 + z'^2 - c^2t'^2 = x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - c^2t^2x′2+y′2+z′2−c2t′2=x2+y2+z2−c2t2(11a)

is satisficd identically. That is to say: If we substitute their expressions in x,y,x,tx, y, x, tx,y,x,t, in place of x′,y′,x′,t′x', y', x', t'x′,y′,x′,t′, on the left-hand side, then the left-hand side of (11a) agrees with the right-hand side.

Appendix II. Minkowski’s Four-Dimensional Space (“World”) [Supplementary to Section XVII]
